title: 114_hr6484
content: The Act titled "Commission to Study Family Reconstruction Proposals for African-Americans Unjustly Impacted by the 'War on Drugs' Act of 2016" establishes a commission to study and propose solutions for African-Americans affected by the War on Drugs. The Commission to Study Family Reconstruction Proposals for African-Americans impacted by the War on Drugs is established to examine disparities in incarceration and forced prison labor within the African-American community since the ratification of Amendment XIII in 1865. This includes analyzing arrest and imprisonment rates for drug crimes compared to the general population. The Commission to Study Family Reconstruction Proposals for African-Americans will analyze disparities in incarceration rates, mandatory minimums impact, financial consequences, government support for mass incarceration, and private corporations' involvement in the imprisonment of African-Americans. The Commission will examine private corporations' support for mass incarceration of African-Americans, their profits, laws discriminating against African-American prisoners, other forms of discrimination post-release, negative effects of mass incarceration, and recommend ways to educate the public on their findings. The Commission will recommend remedies for the lingering effects of mass incarceration on African-Americans, including the possibility of a formal apology from the US government. The Commission will consider compensating victims of the "War on Drugs" and their descendants, including the amount and form of compensation, and eligibility criteria. A report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will focus on compensating victims of the "War on Drugs" and their descendants, determining the amount and form of compensation, and establishing eligibility criteria. The Commission, composed of 15 members appointed by various officials, must have expertise in African-American studies, Sociology, and Economics. Members serve for life. The Commission, consisting of 15 members with expertise in African-American studies, Sociology, and Economics, serves for life. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The first meeting must be called within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. A quorum is eight members, and a Chair and Vice Chair are elected from among the members. Members receive compensation unless otherwise specified. Members of the Commission receive compensation at the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for GS-18 of the General Schedule. Full-time officers or employees of the United States or Members of Congress serving on the Commission do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. All members are reimbursed for travel, subsistence, and other necessary expenses incurred during the performance of their duties. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission under this Act has the authority to hold hearings, request witnesses and documents, and may request the Attorney General to enforce subpoenas. Subcommittees or members can also take actions authorized by the Commission. Additionally, the Commission can obtain official data directly from government departments or agencies. The Commission can request information from government departments and agencies to fulfill its duties. All federal entities must cooperate and provide requested information to the Commission within legal limits. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission may appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain civil service laws. The staff can be appointed without competitive service rules, and their compensation cannot exceed the rate for GS-18. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants at specified rates. The Commission can procure supplies, services, and property by contract as provided in appropriations Acts. They may also enter into agreements with the Administrator of General Services for administrative services and reimburse the costs from Commission funds. The Commission can enter into contracts with various government agencies, private firms, and institutions for research, surveys, and other necessary activities as specified in appropriations Acts. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report to Congress. The report will remain accessible on a public website. $10,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the provisions of this Act.
